comments.commentBody: What we need is more focus on basics histories and physical and for people not to eat so much. 95% of our health problems would be solved. Technology can get us 1% improvement at the cost of neglecting the other 95%.

Law enforcement officers?

Try imagining this - three of these murderers will likely get out of jail in 15 or so years and have a cushy job waiting for them at the NRA or Fox News.

Now, does that "comfort" you?

1. College health services are not always top-notch and have been known to misdiagnose. From this article, one can infer they didn't take appropriate action. Otherwise, she wouldn't have ended up dehydrated in the ER
2. Mono is not a 'trumped-up, self-serving' situation. I can tell you from first hand experience that an immature college kid (me, for example , years ago) may not understand how serious it is and could lead to hepatitis (again,me).
3. When my own son became ill his 1st year at school, I stayed away, trusting the health service and his friends. Big mistake--he really needed the resources and attention of a parent. Seven years later and I still deeply regret that I wasn't there when he needed me. 4 I find your remarks judgmental and cold-hearted in the extreme.

Maybe their parents were paying bills or cleaning the house while their children were at the park.  On my time off (weekends, because I work), I have to allocate hours and hours to household maintenance.  We send our children outside to our backyard, because we can, or get a friend for a playdate, because we know our neighbors.  Just because someone is not playing with their children all the live long day does not mean that they don't love their children or that their children are missing out.  Some parents aren't interested in the type of play their children engage in, anyway.  I'm not, but that doesn't mean I don't appreciate my children as individuals.

its slightly more complex than your final question asks. stand down or fight the bureacracy. there is no question that children in other countries have greater independence, and that USA people are seen the world over as more than a bit on the childish and immature side. moreover, its also true that Americans from USA (i dont mean Americans from Mexico or Guyana by the term American) tend to extend their adolescence until 30 in a large way and until 40 or 50 or longer in smaller ways. I would want to find out from these parents why they choose such a  busy street to make their stand on....but i sure dont support martyrizing the kids just to make a point. P.S.: on the homework. while i agree you dont want to be a hovercraft mom about the nightly homework, that, too, depends on the kid. i WISH i had had a parent check my homework as a kid, because i did need help with math (and there was no one to ask). i wonder how you would handle it if your kid was failing one of their subjects?
ACW - people went to her blog for the vaccination information.
Around here, we moms say, "You get what you get and you don't pitch a fit."

This is such a familiar story. From thousands of miles away, I had the same call from my college sophomore son a few months ago. After freaking out from the size of his tonsils and the pain of swallowing, he had taken a taxi to the nearest urgent care place and was diagnosed with mono.  I had chicken soup delivered also and we texted frequently to keep him from talking but after a couple of days, I knew I needed to hop on a plane. It was expensive but not as much as having to drop classes if he couldn't get back on his feet. We spent three days in a hotel room, just focused on rest and lots of cold liquids per doctors orders. He needed the time to heal and it was good for both of us.

You may have assumed the father "knew what he was doing."  The woman who was killed by her chimp a few years ago "knew what she was doing."  The guy in the Denver area who was killed by his python "knew what he was doing."   Those kids may have been lucky.  A person who drives around with a tiger loose in the car is not just endangering himself and his kids; he's also endangering you and anyone else who looks like lunch to the tiger.
Sorry, I meant to say that this was likely not the first time that you won't be able to do exactly what you'd hoped.

I agree that we should be asking ourselves why the system seems so upset about two kids with very involved parents (we may disagree with their decisions on allowing the kids to walk to the park, but everything I have read indicate a they are very active parents, they just think their kids are old enough to play unsupervised at a park close to their home) while little Relisha's disappearance went unnoticed by not only her teachers but the social workers at the homeless shelter where she was living with her mother for over a month. And I think that Relisha's case should still be news, and there should have  been changes to the system so far and there haven't been. But it should also be noted that the two cases are actually in different jurisdictions: this family lives in Montgomery County, Maryland, Relisha lived in Washington, DC.

"Did I mention no academic skills?"

I am a preschool teacher at a play based school - trust me, if your child was playing - there were lots of academic skills she was learning. The BEST, most developmentally appropriate way for preschool age children to learn is through play. Just because you saw dirt, chocolate milk and paint, does not mean there were no academics as well. There were - they just looked different than a worksheet.

No argument from me. There were no worksheets (thank goodness), but unlike the pricey preK, my daughter's preK did not sit the kids down and teach reading lessons or math lessons, etc.
Instead, they incorporated skills like counting, reading sight words, etc during play.
It was so sweet and just perfect. Of course she learned, she just wasn't sat down and "assessed."

My son went to a fancy, expensive, selective church-based preschool from age 3-5. He seemed to like it, but he was 3. The carpool line was basically a parade of the newest, most expensive SUVs. The kids wore the cutest uniforms and he even had a monogrammed book bag (required by the school). Some of his classmates had to have bodyguards because they were so rich. The school stressed academic skills. The little ones attended chapel in a chapel that looked like it was lined in mahogany. I felt like I was giving him the best preschool experience possible.

With my second child, I snapped out of it. She went to a church preschool, no uniforms, kids came out covered in dirt, chocolate milk, paint and, often, band-aids. No academic skills--just play, naps, songs and lunch bunch. The moms showed up in minivans and older cars and workout clothes. Did I mention no academic skills? She LOVED it. We LOVED it.

My daughter's sophomore year GPA is a bit higher than my son's was his sophomore year. I chalk it up to the fun, crazy, dump-the-rock-out-of-her-shoes-every-afternoon preK. My advice to Kristina is to snap out of it.

If you can't be happy without the best, you can't be happy.

Thanks for your thoughtful insights and willingness to share, Eilene! Young adults' becoming independent is a process, a transition, not an instant transformation. Every parent has to use his or her own knowledge of a particular child and situation to exercise good judgment about when to step in.  What you did sounds about right to me, for a freshman who is seriously ill, if the family can afford it. What a blessing yours could.  She'll continue to grow in independence, and you'll have to keep letting go, but that wasn't really the point of your essay, was it?  It was that you and your daughter got an unexpected chance to rediscover each other and renew your loving bonds.  Hugs to you both.
You sound like a wonderful teacher and mentor. I work in higher ed too, and even the most mature, brightest students need to know that someone cares about their wellbeing.

Right you are! Americans are so ignorant of our history! Look up the most decorated Marine in the nation's history, General Smedley Butler. Read what a real hero had to say about war profiteers and corporations pushing America into war. Read what Gen. Dwight Eisenhower had to say about the military-industrial
complex 60 years ago, and look at where we are now. Rumsfeld and Wolfowitz wouldn't be fit to polish his shoes. They, simply are traitors to America.
I agree except for the assumption that our soldiers feel answerable, are more honorable, and don't commit atrocities. My Lai is just one.

Oh yes, Cheney, Rumsfeld, Wolfowitz and crew made Blackwater founder, Erik Prince, a billionaire. Halliburton made almost 40 billion, and I bet Dick Cheney got a piece of that action.

These guys are out there defending the indefensible, and promoting another war in the Middle East. Being a war profiteer used to be looked down on. Now it's seen as just good business.

When we go to war, it can't be done with mercenaries who get paid a lot more than our soldiers and are answerable to no one. We see what happened and it will happen again.

"Other witnesses described a mother who pushed her daughter to safety, only to be killed herself. One man was pounded with bullets while he lay dying, unarmed, in the street. Another was shot while he had his hands up."

You're right, it took real bravery to do these things.

Let's just hope the sentences stick. They can't bring the innocent dead back to life - that would be the only true justice, so this will have to do.

While I put the majority of the blame squarely on the shoulders of the jokers that lead us into this fiasco, and who collaborated with privateers like Blackwater to move taxpayer money into the coffers of these scam companies and create these opportunities for chaos, there is no question these cowboys acted without honor, and with malice, or worse, complete indifference. And then not having the honor to own up to their actions - not a hint of esprit de corps to be found. There should be no place for mercenaries in the U.S. If a politician wants an army, then raise it if you dare and face the consequences, but don't backdoor it through privatizing war.

Yawn? 17 innocent people die, and you...yawn? Against all military-industrial-judicial-complex odds, these unsupervised vicious killers are convicted.

And you yawn.

I agree with professor Lee in several fronts.  First, the element of Asian philosophy is completely excluded in his opinion which shows his narrow-mindedness.  Secondly, Sartwell makes it seem that all aspects/disciplines of today are materialistic to some degree.  This obviously is not the case.  One simple example of a huge relativistic perspective is in area of quantum physics where the external thing depends on the observer internal stuff.  I will have my own comments below, but I just wanted to support Professor Lee's comment.

@ Nank, I appreciate but many parents perhaps don't understand the simple fact that the physical presence of the parent or parents matter most to the children in adversity no matter how grown up a son or daughter is. There's something called morale boosting, very much needed by the children when matters.
Is this really the best defense you can mount?
Amazing how thoroughly Bremer screwed things up.  How did this man get the job?

Those children were apparently found in a parking lot where there was also a homeless man aware of their presence. That does not mean the children were necessarily in danger but, good Lord, I would have called too, or at least approached the children to make sure they were OK. Problem is, litigation is so prolific in this country, most people are afraid to approach someone else children let alone offer advice to them

There two problems with your response: your bigoted assumptions about homeless people and your willingness to abdicate your responsibility as a fellow human being to look out for other people's children.

Your concern for litigousness rather than taking on an interfering and authoritarian bureaucracy is also a sad commentary on your own willingness to allow an irresponsible government agency to destroy parents' reasonable relationship with their children.

You are reading more into my response than is written. As I wrote, the presence of a homeless man may or may not mean the children were in danger, other than being in a parking lot. I also did not say I would not offer help, I actually would being a mother of three young girls. What I did write was that I can understand how people  may not choose to extend a hand to a stranger's children. You should not jump to conclusions or be so mean.

The thing that strikes me most is what a terrible thing that neighbor did by calling 911 on the parents because s/he saw the children walking alone. I wonder if the person has some grudge against the family. It is the parents' place to decide whether those intersections are appropriate for their children (remember that individual children have different capacities for responsibility); to try to supplant the other parents' judgement with their own was wrong at a minimum, but genuinely abhorrent if the person knew the situation and that the children would end up in the clutches of CPS. If a child is being beaten or abused, certainly call 911. But to knowingly make a report that would result in children being taken away from stable, responsible parents because you have a different parenting style... sickening.

"The real crime is that there was no good reason for that country to be invaded. Everybody with a brain realizes this. "

True. But brain-bearing Americans make up less than 12% of the country. The rest now want to attack Iran. America is one giant psych ward.
We'll see if you feel the same way when a group of "ill-trained security guards" (making 1000 bucks a day) "accidentally" massacres your entire family.
